{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} The '''''Aegean Sea'' tanker oil spill''' was a [[oil spill|spill]] that occurred on 3 December 1992 when the double-bottomed Greek-flagged [[oil tanker]], ''Aegean Sea'', en route to the [[Repsol]] refinery in [[A Coruña]], Spain, suffered an accident off the [[Galicia (Spain)|Galician]] coast. The ship had successfully passed all required tests and revisions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cedre.fr/uk/spill/aegean_sea/aegean_sea.htm|title=Aegean Sea | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927031315/http://www.cedre.fr/uk/spill/aegean_sea/aegean_sea.htm| archivedate= 27 September 2007| deadurl= no|accessdate=28 August 2012}}</ref> The accident occurred during extreme weather conditions and affected the Galician coast resulting in ecosystem damage, as well as damage to the fishing and tourist industries in A Coruña. The captain and pilot were found to be criminally liable and the shipowner took on much of the monetary liability.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:AnclaMarEgeo.jpg|thumb|upright|The anchor of ''Aegean Sea'' at [[Aquarium Finisterrae]] in [[A Coruña]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], Spain ]]
==Incident== After being anchored for a few days off the coast of [[A Coruña]] due to weather hazards, ''Aegean Sea'' was ordered into port by port authorities. Due to this, on 3 December 1992, the oil-ore Greek carrier ship ''Aegean Sea'', ran aground off the coast of Galicia at nearly 5 a.m.<ref>Press. (4 December 1992). The Post and Courier – Google News Archive Search. Google News. Retrieved 28 April 2013, from https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2482&dat=19921204&id=z1ZSAAAAIBAJ</ref> The ship was on its route to A Coruña, Spain, from Sullom Voe, Scotland. Allegedly, a heavy storm managed to push the ship off course and cause her to run aground. A rescue team was sent immediately but failed to keep the ship from breaking in half. This caused the cargo of [[light crude oil]] to be spilled which affected sea life. A temporary evacuation of the city of A Coruña was implemented in order to protect the citizens from the hazards of the oil smoke. Out of the 79,000 tonnes of crude oil that the ship was carrying, 67,000 tonnes managed to be spilled and the remaining was salvaged. The salvaged oil was retained through the use of booms, skimmers, and pumps. Since half of the ship was still above water, the rescue team used pumps to drain the still intact tanks. Soon after, the ship caught on fire and continued to burn for a period of five days. The remaining oil drifted with the strong currents produced by the wind, and as much as 300 km of coast line were affected by the spill. As for the thirty-two-man crew, a rescue helicopter managed to save all of them.<ref name=":0">Aegean Sea. (n.d.). Cedre : Centre de documentation, de recherche et d'expérimentations sur les pollutions accidentelles des eaux. Retrieved 21 April 2013, from http://www.cedre.fr/en/spill/aegean_sea/ae</ref>
As the vessel prepared to enter the docks of A Coruña, the wind speed was above {{convert|50|knots|abbr=on}}, and visibility was under {{convert|100|m|yd|abbr=on}}, causing her to lose her assigned course. ''Aegean Sea'' broke up and exploded with {{convert|50|m|ft|adj=on|abbr=on}} flames near the [[Tower of Hercules]], spilling more than 70,000 tons of oil into the ocean.
The two anchors of ''Aegean Sea'' were recovered, and are now on display at [[Aquarium Finisterrae]] in A Coruña, and at the Philippe Cousteau Museum at Salinas, [[Asturias]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/hemeroteca/2004/10/23/3139480.shtml |title=El "Mar Egeo" y otros buques desmantelados |language=Spanish |accessdate=28 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208022411/http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/hemeroteca/2004/10/23/3139480.shtml |archivedate=8 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Clean-up process== Clean-up crews were immediately sent to the disaster site, both on and offshore. Oil booms were placed around the spill in order to contain the oil. The booms collected around 5,000 cubic meters of an oil/water mixture. On shore, 1,200 cubic meters of contaminated sand and debris were treated for oil. Since only the bow of ''Aegean Sea'' had sunk, pumps were placed in the stern that pumped out the remaining oil.<ref name="tankers">Aegean Sea "Tankers, Big Oil and Pollution Liability." (n.d.). Tankers, Big Oil and Pollution Liability. Retrieved 21 April 2013, from {{cite web |url=http://www.oilpollutionliability.com/aegean-sea/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812210343/http://www.oilpollutionliability.com/aegean-sea/ |archivedate=12 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Aftermath and investigation== The Aegean Sea oil spill affected countless amounts of sea life. A Coruña's fishing industry received the hardest blow, with the ban of all fishing by the Fisheries Council. A claim for fishermens' assistance that totalled nearly 3.53 million dollars was implemented soon after the oil spill. Although the Fisheries Council aided the fishers with some reimbursements, these were nowhere close to fully compensating the fishermens' losses. A flood of claims from fishermen and the tourist industry came to the Spanish Court, totalling around 287 million dollars by 2001. Most of these claims were settled, but some claims remain litigious. The International Oil Pollution Compensation (IOPC), the Spanish Government, and the ship owner finally came to a settlement, with the last payment made in December 2003.<ref name="tankers" /> In addition to the monetary settlements, the captain, Constantine Stavrides, and the pilot were also found criminally liable for negligence and for failing to follow regulations.<ref name="tankers" />
==Hydrocarbon study== [[Hydrocarbon]]s, being a significant source of energy due to their strong chemical bonds, were a prime source for scientific study in the Aegean Sea oil spill. Chemical markers were placed in a sample of the crude oil spilled, with interesting data revealed. Alkanes and acyclic hydrocarbons, both having single bonds, appeared to have deteriorated in only six months, while triterpane and steranane were still present after years of weathering. Both triterpane and steranane have multiple bonds, which is the reason they were still present after so many years. Researchers concluded that chemical markers can be of effective use against oil spills. These markers can allow scientists to determine how long the oil has contaminated seawater, and how the seawater affects the oil collected with water. This can be helpful in the process where spilled oil is collected and processed for reuse. Chemical markers may now be placed in the oil to determine how much the oil must be cleaned to be satisfactory for use.<ref name="Pastor 2001" />
==Ecosystem study== The Galician coast was an extremely vital source of income for Spain's fishing industry. Crab and lobster harvesting, salmon farming, and the main profit industry of shellfish farming were all affected by the spill. Soon after the oil spill, Spain ordered a study of the ecosystem in order to evaluate the damage done to the benthic fauna in the region, and muddy sediments.<ref name="Pastor 2001">{{cite journal|last1=Pastor |first1=D. |last2=Sanchez |first2=J. |last3=Porte |first3=C. |last4=Albaiges |first4=J. |year=2001 |title=The Aegean Sea Oil Spill in the Galicia coast (NW Spain). I. Distribution and fate of the Crude Oil and Combustion Products in Subtidal Sediments |url=http://otvm.uvigo.es/investigacion/informes/documentos/archivos/aegean%20sea%20distribution.pdf |format=PDF |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=42 |issue=10 |pages=895–904 |doi=10.1016/s0025-326x(01)00048-0 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620222818/http://otvm.uvigo.es/investigacion/informes/documentos/archivos/aegean%20sea%20distribution.pdf |archivedate=20 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> This study was enforced due to the fact that an earlier oil spill had occurred in the same area: on 12 May 1976, the supertanker ''Urquiola'' scraped the bottom of the channel entrance in A Coruña, causing the ship to spill its cargo of 107,000 tons of oil. This affected sea life as well as subtidal sediments, but the surviving sea life developed defense mechanisms which allowed them to survive such a crisis. The sea life in A Coruña appeared to remain stable until the wreck of the ''Aegean Sea''.
To determine the impact of the spill on sea life, a study was conducted to determine species richness, abundance, and biomass. Scientist analyzed changes from December 1992 to November 1996, and found that the [[Macrobenthos|macrobenthic]] communities living in the coast of the affected areas displayed a similar trend as the original organisms affected by the ''Urquiola''{{'}}s oil spill. [[Amphipoda|Amphipods]] seemed to be affected the worst by the oil spill, and experienced a high mortality rate and low abundance rate, up to the spring of 1995. Soon after, the species seemed to recover until the end of the study in 1996. Towards the end of the study, a trend was discovered in which resistant species dominated the ecosystem.
A third oil spill occurred around the same area in A Coruña in November 2002, in which a tanker, [[Prestige oil spill|''Prestige'']], carrying 77,000 tons of oil split into two and spilled its cargo. About 10,000 tons of oil was spilled but the sunken hull of ''Prestige'' is still leaking oil from her tanks to this day{{when|date=January 2016}}.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gomez Gesteira |first1=J.L. |last2=Dauvin |first2=J.C. |year=2004 |title=Impact of the Aegean Sea oil spill on the subtidal fine sand macrobenthic community of the Ares-Betanzos Ria (Northwest Spain) |url=http://otvm.uvigo.es/investigacion/informes/documentos/archivos/aegeansea_gomezgesteira.pdf |format=PDF |journal=Marine Environmental Research |volume=60 |issue= |pages=289–316 |doi=10.1016/j.marenvres.2004.11.001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130619210721/http://otvm.uvigo.es/investigacion/informes/documentos/archivos/aegeansea_gomezgesteira.pdf |archivedate=19 June 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>

McKernan Jr.|John McKernan]] |successor1 = [[John Baldacci]] |birth_name = Angus Stanley King Jr. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|03|31}} |birth_place = [[Alexandria, Virginia]], U.S. |death_date = |party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] (1993–present) |otherparty = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (before 1993) |spouse = {{plainlist| * {{marriage|Edith C. Hazard||1982|end=divorced}} * {{marriage|Mary Herman|1984}}}} |children = 5 |education = [[Dartmouth College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[University of Virginia]] ([[Bachelor of Laws|JD]]) |website = {{url|https://king.senate.gov|Senate website}} |signature = AngusKingSignature.png }} '''Angus Stanley King Jr.''' (born March 31, 1944) is an American politician and attorney serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|junior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Maine]] since 2013.{{cite web |author=Angus S. King |url=http://digitalcommons.bowdoin.edu/mitchelloralhistory/105/ |title="Interview with Angus King by Andrea L’Hommedieu" by Angus S. King |publisher=Digitalcommons.bowdoin.edu |date= |accessdate=November 13, 2012}} A [[Independent politician|political independent]] since 1993, he was the [[List of Governors of Maine|72nd]] [[Governor of Maine]] from 1995 to 2003. King won Maine's [[United States Senate election in Maine, 2012|2012 Senate election]] to replace the retiring [[Republican Party of Maine|Republican]] [[Olympia Snowe]] and took office on January 3, 2013. He was reelected to his second term in [[United States Senate election in Maine, 2018|2018]], following the state's inaugural [[instant-runoff voting]] elections. For [[List of current United States Senate committees|committee]] assignment purposes, he [[Congressional caucus|caucuses]] with the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. He is one of two independents currently serving in the Senate, the other being [[Bernie Sanders]] of [[Vermont]]. ==Early life, education, and early career== King was born in [[Alexandria, Virginia]], the son of Ellen Archer (née Ticer) and Angus Stanley King Sr., a lawyer.{{cite web|author=|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/2006-05-25/news/0605250194_1_mrs-king-holy-cross-williamsburg-landing |title=Ellen Archer Ticer King – Daily Press |publisher=Articles.dailypress.com |date=May 25, 2006 |accessdate=November 13, 2012}} He graduated from [[Dartmouth College]] in 1966 with a B.A. and the [[University of Virginia School of Law]] in 1969 with a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] While a student at Dartmouth, King joined the [[Delta Upsilon]] social fraternity.{{cite web|title=Greeks in the 113th Congress |url=http://www.nicindy.org/blog/greeks-in-the-113th-congress/ |publisher=North-American Interfraternity Conference |accessdate=September 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327052229/http://www.nicindy.org/blog/greeks-in-the-113th-congress/ |archivedate=March 27, 2014 }} Soon after graduation from Virginia, King entered private law practice in [[Brunswick, Maine]]. He was a staff attorney for Pine Tree Legal Assistance in [[Skowhegan, Maine|Skowhegan]]. In 1972, he served as chief [[counsel]] to the U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Alcoholism and Narcotics. King served as a legislative assistant to Democratic U.S. Senator [[William Hathaway]] in the 1970s. He was also well-known statewide as a television host on [[Maine Public Broadcasting Network|public television]].Nemitz, Bill, [http://www.pressherald.com/politics/king-passes-his-first-100-days-as-senator-eventfully_2013-04-14.html?pagenum=full "King’s first 100 days: ‘The hardest I’ve ever worked in my life’"], Portland ''Press Herald'', April 14, 2013. Retrieved April 30, 2013. In 1973, when he was 29, King was diagnosed with an aggressive form of malignant [[melanoma]]. King has said he believes he survived cancer only because he had health insurance, and he has highlighted this experience when explaining his support for the [[Affordable Care Act]].{{cite web|last1=TAMC Communication and Development|title=Senator Angus King to present keynote address at May 9 County Cancer Conference|url=http://bangordailynews.com/community/senator-angus-king-to-present-keynote-address-at-may-9-county-cancer-conference/|website=Bangor Daily News|accessdate=November 14, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Pierce|first1=Charles|title="These Are People. This Isn't Ideology. These Are People."|url=https://www.esquire.com/news-politics/politics/news/a53047/angus-king-tom-price/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Esquire|date=February 10, 2017}} In 1975, King returned to Maine to practice with Smith, Loyd and King in Brunswick. In 1983, he was appointed vice president of Swift River/Hafslund Company, which developed alternative energy (hydro and biomass) projects in [[New England]]. In 1989, King founded Northeast Energy Management, Inc., a company that developed and operated electrical energy conservation projects. In 1994, he sold the company. In 2012, King's investments were valued at between $4.8 million and $22.5 million.{{cite news|last1=Richardson|first1=John|title=King is wealthy, but not through wind projects|url=https://www.centralmaine.com/2012/06/28/king-files-report-detailing-his-wealth_2012-06-28/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Portland Press Herald|date=June 28, 2012}} ==Governor of Maine== ===1994 election=== {{Main|Maine gubernatorial election, 1994}} In May 1993, King announced he would run for [[governor of Maine]] as an independent, as incumbent Governor [[John McKernan]], a Republican, was term-limited and could not seek another term.{{cite news|last=Higgins|first=A. Jay|title=Lewiston mayor to make Blaine House bid|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=May 7, 1993}} King abandoned his lifelong affiliation with the [[Maine Democratic Party]]. "The Democratic Party as an institution has become too much the party that is looking for something from government," King explained to the ''[[Bangor Daily News]]'' a few weeks after he announced he would be running.{{cite news|last=Ripley|first=John|title=Candidate King maps course to Augusta|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=May 18, 1993}} The [[Maine Republican Party|Republican]] nominee was [[Susan Collins]], Commissioner of Professional and Financial Regulation under Governor [[John McKernan]] and a [[protégé]]e of U.S. Senator [[William Cohen]], and at the time relatively unknown to the electorate. The Democratic nominee was former Governor and U.S. Representative [[Joseph E. Brennan]]. It was Brennan's fifth campaign for governor. The general election was a highly competitive four-way race between King, Collins, Brennan, and [[Green Party USA|Green Party]] nominee [[Jonathan Carter (politician)|Jonathan Carter]]. King decided to invest early in television advertising during Maine's unusually early June primary, allowing him to emerge from the primary season on an equal footing with his rivals. King positioned himself as a businessman and a pragmatic environmentalist focused on job creation and education.{{cite news|title=AD DEPICTS KING AS USING NEW IDEAS TO ENCOURAGE JOBS|newspaper=Portland Press Herald|date=October 1, 1994}} ''[[The Washington Times]]'' described him as an idealist who "wants to slash regulations but preserve the environment; hold the line on taxes; impose work and education requirements on welfare recipients; experiment with public school choice and cut at least $60 million from the state budget."{{cite news|last=Snow|first=Tony|title=Maine bellwether for voter discontent?|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=July 9, 1994}} His opponents criticized him for flip-flopping. Collins argued King "presents different images, depending on who he is talking to. Angus has been a Democrat his whole life. In my opinion, he became an independent because he didn't think he could beat Joe Brennan in a primary. He's extremely smooth, articulate and bright, but he says different things to different groups."{{cite news|last=Hale|first=John|title=A King pursues top spot > Former liberal now sees himself as `pragmatic'|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=October 4, 1994}} King narrowly won the November 8 election with 35% of the vote to Brennan's 34%, a margin of just 7,878 votes. (Collins received 23% of the vote and Carter 6%.) King won eight counties, Collins five and Brennan three.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=29040|title=Our Campaigns - ME Governor Race - Nov 08, 1994|publisher=Ourcampaigns.com|accessdate=October 11, 2014}} King's election as an independent was not unprecedented in Maine politics, as independent [[James B. Longley]] had been elected twenty years earlier. ===1998 election=== {{Main|Maine gubernatorial election, 1998}} King won reelection to a second term in 1998 with 59% of the vote. He defeated Republican [[James B. Longley Jr.|Jim Longley Jr.]] (the son of the former governor) (19%) and Democrat [[Thomas J. Connolly|Thomas Connolly]] (12%). King's 59% was the highest a candidate had received since Brennan's [[Maine gubernatorial election, 1982|1982]] reelection with 62% of the vote. Brennan's 1982 victory was also the last time before 1998 that a gubernatorial candidate had won a majority of the vote, and King's 1998 reelection remains the last time in a Maine gubernatorial election that the winner got a majority. ===Tenure=== [[File:Russians presents their social project to Maine governor Angus King.jpg|thumb|right|King meets with a Russian delegation as Maine governor in October 2002.|260x260px]] During his tenure, King was the only [[Governor (United States)|governor]] in the United States unaffiliated with any political party. He was also one of only two governors nationwide not affiliated with either of the two major parties, the other being [[Jesse Ventura]] of [[Minnesota]], who was elected in 1998 as a member of the [[Reform Party of the United States of America|Reform Party]]. The term of Connecticut's independent governor [[Lowell Weicker]] ended when King's began. In his book ''Independent Nation'' (2004), political analyst [[John Avlon]] describes all three governors as [[Radical center (politics)|radical centrist]] thinkers.Avlon, John (2004). ''Independent Nation: How the Vital Center Is Changing American Politics''. Harmony Books / Random House, pp. 177–93 ("Radical Centrists"). {{ISBN|978-1-4000-5023-9}}. In 2002, King launched the [[Maine Learning Technology Initiative]] (MLTI) to provide laptops for every public middle-school student in the state, the first initiative of its kind in the nation.{{cite journal|last=Waters|first=John|title=Maine Ingredients|journal=T.H.E. Journal|year=2009|volume=36|issue=8|pages=35}} It met with considerable resistance due to its cost but was enacted by the [[Maine Legislature]]. On September 5, 2002, the state began the program with a four-year $37.2-million contract with [[Apple Inc.]] to equip all 7th- and 8th-grade students and teachers in the state with laptops.{{cite news|last1=Cousins|first1=Christopher|title=LePage eyes changing laptop program launched by Angus King|url=https://bangordailynews.com/2016/08/12/politics/state-house/lepage-eyes-changing-laptop-program-launched-by-angus-king/|accessdate=15 March 2018|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=August 12, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Herold|first1=Benjamin|last2=Kazi|first2=Jason|title=Maine 1-to-1 Computing Initiative Under Microscope|url=https://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2016/08/31/maine-1-to-1-computing-initiative-under-microscope.html|accessdate=15 March 2018|publisher=Education Week|date=August 30, 2016}} As governor, King signed legislation requiring that all school employees be fingerprinted and undergo [[background check]]s. Alan K. Ota, [http://public.cq.com/docs/news/news-000004172396.html 113th Congress: Angus King, I-Maine (Senate)], ''CQ Today'' (November 6, 2012). ==Post-gubernatorial career (2003–2013)== The day after he left office in 2003, King, his wife, Mary Herman, and their two children, who were 12 and 9 at the time, embarked on a road trip in a 40-foot motor home to see America. Over the next six months, the family traveled 15,000 miles and visited 33 states before returning home in June 2003.{{cite news|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2011/06/24/politics/angus-king-chronicles-rv-travels-in-new-book/ | title=Angus King chronicles RV travels in new book|date=June 24, 2011|accessdate=January 13, 2015|author=Canfield, Clarke|agency=Associated Press}} During his post-gubernatorial residency in Maine, he lectured at [[Bowdoin College]] in [[Brunswick, Maine|Brunswick]] and [[Bates College]] in [[Lewiston, Maine|Lewiston]]. He was appointed a visiting lecturer at Bowdoin in 2004 and an endowed lecturer at Bates in 2009, teaching courses in [[Politics of the United States|American politics]] and [[Statecraft (political science)|political leadership]] at both institutions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bates.edu/news/2009/10/29/bates-to-host-political-forums/|title=Bates to host Maine political forums|last=|first=|date=October 29, 2009|work=Bates Magazine|access-date=November 10, 2018|language=en}}{{cite news|title=Angus King|url=https://dailysun.bowdoin.edu/angus-king/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Bowdoin Daily Sun}} In 2007, King and Rob Gardiner, formerly of the [[Maine Public Broadcasting Network]], formed Independence Wind, a wind energy company.{{cite news|last1=Richardson|first1=John|title=Angus King defends his wind career|url=https://www.pressherald.com/2012/09/15/angus-king-defends-his-wind-career_2012-09-16/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Portland Press Herald|date=September 15, 2012}} In August 2009, Independence Wind along with joint venture partner Wagner Forest Management won Maine DEP approval for construction of a proposed $120-million, 22-turbine, utility-scale wind power project along a prominent mountain ridge in [[Roxbury, Maine]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mainebiz.biz/news45086.html |title=DEP approves Record Hill wind farm | Mainebiz |publisher=Mainebiz.biz |date= |accessdate=September 14, 2011}} To avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest, King sold his share of the company after entering the [[United States Senate election in Maine, 2012|2012 U.S. Senate election]].{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/03/22/energy/panel-raises-questions-about-102m-loan-guarantee-for-wind-project/|title=Panel questions loan guarantee for wind project in which Angus King had stake|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=March 22, 2012|accessdate=May 30, 2012}} Of the project, King has said, "People who say wind is only an intermittent resource are looking for a one-shot solution. And my experience is that there are rarely silver bullets, but there is often silver buckshot. Wind is an adjunct source of energy. Ten percent, 20% can be very significant".{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Taylor|title=Running with the wind|url=http://www.mainebiz.biz/article/20071210/CURRENTEDITION/312109987|publisher=Mainbiz.biz|accessdate=October 13, 2012}} ==United States Senate== ===Elections=== {{Main|United States Senate election in Maine, 2012}} On March 5, 2012, King announced that he was running for the [[U.S. Senate]] seat being vacated by [[Olympia Snowe]].{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/02/29/politics/mike-michaud-enters-senate-race/? |title=Michaud, Pingree and Baldacci may seek Olympia Snowe’s seat; King, Raye and Cutler also considering |publisher=Bangor Daily News |date= |accessdate=March 1, 2012}}{{cite web | last =Riskind | first =Jonathan | title = Source: King to run for Snowe's seat | url = http://www.pressherald.com/news/King-has-made-up-his-mind-Pingree-hasnt.html | publisher = The Portland Press Herald / Maine Sunday Telegram | date =March 5, 2012 | accessdate = March 5, 2012 }} King said "hogwash" to allegations by some Republicans that he had cut a deal with Democrats to keep U.S. Rep. [[Chellie Pingree]] out of the race.{{cite web|url=http://www.kjonline.com/news/King-supports-Obama-for-re-election.html |title=King supports Obama for re-election |publisher=www.kjonline.com |date= |accessdate=March 9, 2012}} King's Senate campaign came under scrutiny for posting a heavily edited newspaper profile of him to the campaign website.{{cite news|last1=Shepherd|first1=Michael|title=King’s campaign altered newspaper article on website|url=http://www.pressherald.com/politics/King-alters-newspaper-article-on-website.html|accessdate=August 15, 2014|publisher=Portland Press Herald|date=September 24, 2012}} On November 6, 2012, King won the Senate race with 53%{{cite news|title=Election Center|url=http://www.cnn.com/election/2012/results/state/ME/senate|work=Senate: Maine|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 14, 2012}} of the vote, beating Democrat [[Cynthia Dill]] and Republican [[Charlie Summers]].{{cite news|title=Angus King wins Senate bid|url=http://www.wcsh6.com/news/article/221223/2/Angus-King-wins-Senate-bid|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209045309/http://www.wcsh6.com/news/article/221223/2/Angus-King-wins-Senate-bid|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 9, 2013|newspaper=WCSH|date=November 7, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Sharp|first=David|title=King wins Senate race; gay marriage OK'd in Maine|url=http://www.stamfordadvocate.com/news/article/King-wins-Senate-race-gay-marriage-OK-d-in-Maine-4017679.php|newspaper=Stamford Advocate, Associated Press|date=November 7, 2012}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}} The following week, King announced that he would caucus with Senate Democrats, explaining not only that it made more sense to affiliate with the party that had a clear majority, but that he would have been largely excluded from the committee process had he not caucused with a party.{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Kevin|title=King will caucus with Senate Democrats|url=http://www.kjonline.com/news/angus-king-caucus-senate-democrats.html|newspaper=Kennebec Journal|date=November 14, 2012}}{{cite news|last=O'Keefe|first=Ed|title=Angus King to caucus with Democrats in Senate|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/wp/2012/11/14/angus-king-to-caucus-with-democrats-in-senate/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=November 14, 2012}} King said he had not ruled out caucusing with the Republicans if they took control of the Senate in 2014,{{cite news|last=Recio |first=Maria |title=McMorris Rodgers wins fight for spot in House GOP leadership |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2019683952_congress15.html |newspaper=The Seattle Times |date=November 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427210916/http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2019683952_congress15.html |archivedate=April 27, 2014 }} but when that happened, he remained in the Democratic caucus. ===Tenure=== [[File:U.S. Coast Guard Adm. Robert J. Papp Jr., right, commandant of the Coast Guard, and Vice Adm. John P. Currier, left, vice commandant of the Coast Guard, pose for a photograph with Sen. Angus S. King Jr 130423-G-OY189-019.jpg|thumb|268x268px|King with [[Coast guard|Coast Guard]] officials in Washington, 2013.]] King supports reform of the Senate [[filibuster]], noting that senators are no longer required to stand on the floor and speak during a filibuster. He also points out that the Constitution contains no 60-vote requirement to conduct business in the Senate.{{primary source inline|date=March 2018}} Accordingly, in 2013 King voted in favor of the so-called [[Nuclear option (U.S. politics)|nuclear option]] to eliminate the [[Filibuster in the United States Senate|filibuster]] for most presidential nominees.{{cite web| title=King Statement on Vote to Alter Filibuster Rule| url= https://www.king.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/king-statement-on-vote-to-alter-filibuster-rule| publisher= Office of Sen. Angus King| date = November 21, 2013| accessdate = December 7, 2013}}{{primary source inline|date=March 2018}} King opposes attempts by the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House]] to cut $40 billion from the [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program]] over ten years, fearing that it "would affect people in a serious way" and drive more people to soup kitchens and food banks. He supports the more modest Senate efforts to save $4 billion over the same period by closing loopholes.{{cite news|last=Koeing|first=Seth|title=Angus King says $40 billion in proposed House cuts to food stamp program too much|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/10/24/politics/angus-king-says-40-billion-in-proposed-house-cuts-to-food-stamp-program-too-much/|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=October 24, 2013|accessdate=October 24, 2013}} In 2014 King was chosen for the annual tradition of reading George Washington's Farewell Address to the Senate.{{cite news|last1=Lesniewski|first1=Neils|title=Senate Hears Washington’s Words Once Again|url=http://blogs.rollcall.com/wgdb/senate-hears-washingtons-words-once-again/|accessdate=July 9, 2014|agency=Roll Call|date=February 24, 2014}} [[File:Hagel, Dempsey testify before Senate 140916-D-KC128-667.jpg|left|thumb|270x270px|[[Martin Dempsey]] (''right''), speaks with King (''left'') at [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Senate Armed Services Committee]] meeting in 2014.]] King endorsed his colleague [[Susan Collins]] for reelection in the [[United States Senate election in Maine, 2014|2014 U.S. Senate election]],{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/05/16/angus-king-endorses-susan-collins-in-her-bid-for-reelection/|title=Sen. Angus King (I) endorses colleagues Collins (R) and Shaheen (D)|work=Washington Post|accessdate=October 11, 2014}} calling her a "model Senator". At the same time, he endorsed Democratic Senator [[Jeanne Shaheen]] of New Hampshire for reelection.{{cite web|url=http://www.kjonline.com/news/King_on_Collins___We_ve_got_a_model_senator_here__.html|title=King on Collins: ‘We’ve got a model senator here’|work=[[Kennebec Journal]]|date=May 16, 2014|accessdate=May 16, 2014}} King also endorsed [[Eliot Cutler]] for governor in the [[Maine gubernatorial election, 2014|2014 election]], as he had done in 2010, although on October 29, 2014, he switched his endorsement to Democratic nominee [[Mike Michaud]].{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/08/18/politics/kings-endorsement-of-cutler-expected-in-portland-this-morning/ |title=Angus King endorses Eliot Cutler at Portland press conference |accessdate=August 18, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2014/10/29/angus-king-switches-endorsement-from-cutler-to-michaud/|title=Angus King switches endorsement from Cutler to Michaud|publisher=Portland Press Herald |date=October 29, 2014 |accessdate=October 29, 2014}} He also endorsed Democrat [[Emily Cain]] for the [[United States House of Representatives elections in Maine, 2014#District 2|Maine's second congressional district]] election{{cite web|author=Michael Shepherd |url=http://www.centralmaine.com/2014/09/30/angus-king-to-endorse-2nd-districts-cain-on-wednesday/ |title=Angus King to endorse 2nd District’s Cain on Wednesday|publisher=KJonline.com |date=October 1, 2014 |accessdate=October 1, 2014}} and Republican Senator [[Lamar Alexander]] of Tennessee in his [[United States Senate election in Tennessee, 2014|reelection campaign]].{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/senate-races/221836-independent-king-endorses-alexander-for-reelection|title=Maine Independent endorses GOP's Alexander|first=Alexandra|last=Jaffe|work=The Hill|date=October 24, 2014|accessdate=October 25, 2014}} After Republicans gained the Senate majority in the [[United States Senate election, 2014|November 4, 2014 election]], King announced that he would continue to caucus with the Democrats. He cited his belief that it is good for a state to have a senator from each party, and that it is important to have a senator who caucuses with the same party as the President, saying, "In the end, who I caucus with is less important than who I work with." He further said, "It does not mean I have become a Democrat. It does not mean I have made a promise to anybody."{{cite web|url=http://www.wcsh6.com/story/news/politics/2014/11/05/senator-king-caucus-democrats/18548955/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20141105223559/http://www.wcsh6.com/story/news/politics/2014/11/05/senator-king-caucus-democrats/18548955/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 5, 2014|title=Senator King to caucus with Democrats|work=WCSH-6 TV|date=November 5, 2014|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} In June 2015, King underwent a successful surgery that removed a [[Prostate cancer|cancerous prostate]] that had been detected in a [[Prostate cancer screening|screening]] and [[biopsy]]. The surgery did not change King's plans to run for reelection in 2018.{{cite news|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2015/06/26/sen-angus-kings-prostate-surgery-is-a-success-his-wife-says/|title=Sen. Angus King’s prostate surgery is a success, his wife says|date=June 26, 2017|author=J. Craig Anderson|work=Press Herald}} ===Committee assignments=== * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Committee on Armed Services]]''' **[[United States Senate Armed Services Subcommittee on Personnel|Subcommittee on Personnel]] **[[United States Senate Armed Services Subcommittee on Seapower|Subcommittee on Seapower]] **[[United States Senate Armed Services Subcommittee on Strategic Forces|Subcommittee on Strategic Forces]] * '''[[United States Senate Committee on the Budget|Committee on the Budget]]''' * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources|Committee on Energy and Natural Resources]]''' **[[United States Senate Energy Subcommittee on Energy|Subcommittee on Energy]] **[[United States Senate Energy Subcommittee on National Parks|Subcommittee on National Parks]] **[[United States Senate Energy Subcommittee on Water and Power|Subcommittee on Water and Power]] * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Rules and Administration|Committee on Rules and Administration]]''' * '''[[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Select Committee on Intelligence]]''' ===Caucus memberships=== * [[Afterschool Caucuses]]{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=http://www.afterschoolalliance.org/policyCongressionalCaucuses.cfm|format=|publisher=Afterschool Alliance|date=|accessdate=18 April 2018}} ==Political positions== King has been described as a [[Centrism|moderate]] Independent.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pressherald.com/2015/02/18/sen-angus-king-builds-a-reputation/|title=For Maine’s Sen. Angus King, moderate stance, unpredictability paying off|date=2015-02-18|work=Press Herald|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en-US}} He has called himself "neither a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] nor a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], but an [[American (word)|American]]".{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-nErGgVEO6U|title=Megan Winchester – Angus King Political Ad 2012|date=October 26, 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}} The nonpartisan ''[[National Journal]]'' gave him a 2013 composite ideology score of 59% liberal and 41% conservative.{{Cite web|url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/22381/angus-king-jr|title=Angus King's Ratings and Endorsements|last=|first=|date=|website=votesmart.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} His Crowdpac score is −4.3 (10 is the most [[conservatism|conservative]], −10 the most [[liberalism|liberal]]), based on a data aggregation of his campaign contributions, votes, and speeches.{{cite web|url=https://www.crowdpac.com/candidates/135344/angus-king|title=Angus King|publisher=}} In a study published by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called "Party Unity scores," King only voted with the Democratic Party 43% of the time.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/07/31/want-a-less-partisan-senator-elect-a-former-governor/|title=Analysis {{!}} Want a less partisan senator? Elect a former governor.|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}} He has also received higher approval ratings from liberal interest groups than conservative ones. King has been rated 89% by the average liberal interest group; the average conservative interest group rates him 14.5%.{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/interest-groups|title=National Special Interest Groups - The Voter's Self Defense System - Vote Smart|work=Project Vote Smart}} [[GovTrack]] ranks King among the more moderate members of the Senate, near the Senate's ideological center.{{Cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/members/angus_king/412545|title=Angus King, Senator for Maine - GovTrack.us|website=GovTrack.us|language=en|access-date=2018-07-23}} In 2014, King endorsed his Republican colleague from Maine, [[Susan Collins]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2014/05/16/senator-collins-earns-king-endorsement-maine/pwu4as3QvQVtUu6MIKjvaK/story.html|title=US Senator Collins earns King’s endorsement in Maine - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2018-10-30}} According to [[FiveThirtyEight]], which tracks Congressional votes, King had voted in line with President Trump's position on legislation about 45% of the time as of July 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/angus-s-king-jr/|title=Tracking Congress In The Age Of Trump|last=Bycoffe|first=Aaron|date=2017-01-30|work=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en-US}} ===Economy=== King has called for the continuation of a tariff on imported athletic footwear and rejects discussing the potential removal of the tariff in trade talks with [[Vietnam]], citing the potential loss of jobs at [[New Balance]]'s [[Skowhegan, Maine|Skowhegan]] and [[Madison, Maine|Madison]] factories in Maine. New Balance is the only remaining domestic manufacturer of athletic footwear.{{cite news|author=John Richardson|url=http://www.kjonline.com/news/King-to-call-for-continued-trade-protection-.html |title=King calls for continued tariff protection for Maine shoes |newspaper=Kennebec Journal |date=August 14, 2012}} Also while governor, King vetoed a bill that would have raised Maine's minimum wage by 25 cents per hour.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/01/us/politics/former-gov-angus-king-leads-maine-senate-race.html|title=Former Gov. Angus King Leads Maine Senate Race|last=Seelye|first=Katharine Q.|date=July 1, 2012|work=The New York Times}} In 2017, King was a strong opponent of the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|Republican tax bill]], criticizing its rushed passage on a party-line vote without hearings,[https://www.cbsnews.com/news/transcript-sen-angus-king-on-face-the-nation-dec-3-2017/ Transcript: Sen. Angus King], ''Face the Nation'', CBS News (December 3, 2017).Kevin Miller, [http://www.pressherald.com/2017/11/30/senate-rejects-kings-attempt-to-send-tax-bill-back-to-committee/ Senate rejects Angus King's attempt to send tax bill back to committee], ''Press Herald'' (November 30, 2017). saying: "The Bangor City Council would not amend the [[Leash#Leash laws|leash law]] using this process." King criticized the legislation for adding $1 trillion to the U.S. budget deficit over ten years and sought to return the bill to committee, but his proposal failed on a party-line vote. ===Foreign relations and national security=== King has voted to arm [[Syrian opposition|Syrian rebels]] who are fighting Syrian President [[Bashar al-Assad]] and [[ISIL]] militants.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/09/18/politics/king-collins-vote-to-approve-arming-syrian-rebels-funding-government/|title=King, Collins vote to approve arming Syrian rebels, funding government|work=The Bangor Daily News|date=September 18, 2014}} In 2015, King gave his support to the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]], an international agreement with Iran. In voting against a "[[Iran Nuclear Agreement Review Act of 2015|resolution of disapproval]]" in opposition to the agreement, King stated, "The current alternatives, if this agreement is rejected, are either unrealistic or downright dangerous."{{cite web|last1=Carney|first1=Jordain|title=Independent Sen. Angus King backs Iran deal|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/250361-independent-sen-angus-king-backs-iran-deal|publisher=TheHill|accessdate=June 8, 2017|date=August 5, 2015}} King favors the [[Cuban thaw|normalization of U.S.–Cuba relations]]. He opposes the [[United States embargo against Cuba|U.S. embargo against Cuba]], calling it an "antiquated" relic of the [[Cold War]]; in 2015, King introduced legislation to lift the embargo.[https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2015/06/14/senator-king-files-bill-restore-trade-with-cuba/c6V2Tt0VJuss9YCyqwgwUN/story.html Senator King files bill to restore trade with Cuba], Associated Press (June 14, 2015).Mario Moretto, [http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2015/06/11/angus-king-introduces-bill-to-re-open-trade-with-cuba/ Angus King introduces bill to re-open trade with Cuba], ''Bangor Daily News'' (June 11, 2015). As a member of the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]], King is participating in its probe of [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russia's interference]] in the 2016 U.S. elections.Christopher Burns, [https://bangordailynews.com/2017/10/29/politics/angus-king-says-its-premature-to-rule-out-collusion-with-russia/ "Angus King says it's 'premature' to rule out collusion with Russia"], ''Bangor Daily News'' (October 31, 2017). King said that the entire committee had "no doubt whatsoever" about the Kremlin's culpability in the meddling and described the cyberattacks as "a frontal assault on our democracy" that could present a long-term threat.Christina Pazzanese, [https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2017/11/we-know-russia-hacked-election-says-sen-king/ {{"'}}We know' Russia hacked election: In Harvard remarks, Sen. Angus King also says such cyberattacks can happen again",] ''Harvard Gazette'' (November 27, 2017). ===Environment and energy=== King supports action to combat [[Global warming|climate change]] and carries a laminated graph of [[Carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere|increases in carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere]] to respond to [[climate change denial]]ists.Geof Koss, [https://www.eenews.net/stories/1060036074 Senator has handy response for science skeptics], [[E&E News]] (April 22, 2016). King was the only member of Congress to join a three-day [[U.S. Coast Guard]] fact-finding mission to [[Greenland]] in 2016, where he witnessed [[Greenland ice sheet|melting ice sheets]] firsthand and said that the impacts of climate change were "amazing and scary."Penelope Overton, [http://www.pressherald.com/2016/08/25/on-fact-finding-trip-to-greenland-sen-angus-king-finds-effect-of-climate-change-amazing-and-scary/ On trip to Greenland, Sen. King finds effect of climate change ‘amazing and scary'], ''Portland Press Herald'' (August 25, 2016). King opposes [[Arctic Refuge drilling controversy|oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]], believing the amount of oil is not worth the environmental risk of extracting it. He also believes that new developments in the energy field, such as [[fracking]], should be subject to "all appropriate environmental safeguards to protect the American people and the American land."{{cite web|url=http://angus2012.com/issues/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725005248/http://angus2012.com/issues/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 25, 2012 |title=Angus on the Issues |publisher=Angus King for U.S. Senate |date= |accessdate=June 22, 2012 }}{{primary source inline|date=March 2018}} King is opposed to the [[Keystone XL pipeline]], stating that the "project will facilitate the transport of some of the world's dirtiest and most climate-harming oil through our country"{{cite web|url=https://www.king.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/king-opposes-keystone-pipeline-will-vote-to-move-to-full-debate|title=Press Release - Press Releases - Newsroom - Angus King - U.S. Senator for Maine|date=January 12, 2015|publisher=}}{{primary source inline|date=March 2018}} and has cast several votes against legislation authorizing its construction.{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=113&session=2&vote=00280|title=U.S. Senate: Roll Call Vote|date=January 27, 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=114&session=1&vote=00003|title=U.S. Senate: Roll Call Vote|date=January 27, 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=114&session=1&vote=00049|title=U.S. Senate: Roll Call Vote|date=January 27, 2015|publisher=}} King has said that he is "frustrated" with President Obama's delay in deciding whether to authorize construction, but that he opposes Congress legislating the approval or disapproval of a construction project.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/11/18/politics/keystone-xl-pipeline-chances-dim-in-senate-as-angus-king-says-no/|title=Angus King casts deciding vote as Keystone XL pipeline bill dies in Senate|work=The Bangor Daily News}} King has expressed opposition to the creation of a Maine Woods National Park, stating on his 2012 campaign website that local control is the best way to conserve land, but in 2014 stating that he was keeping an open mind about the idea.{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/06/10/news/penobscot/national-park-debate-to-reopen-in-northern-penobscot-county-lincoln-chamber-to-hold-informational-meetings/ |title=National park debate to reopen in northern Penobscot County; Lincoln chamber to hold informational meetings |publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=June 10, 2014 |accessdate=June 10, 2014}} King initially expressed "serious reservations" about proposals to establish the [[Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument]],{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2015/11/23/politics/collins-king-poliquin-express-serious-reservations-about-north-woods-national-monument/|title=Collins, King, Poliquin express ‘serious reservations’ about national monument|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date= |accessdate=November 23, 2015}} but expressed support for President Obama's creation of the monument in 2016, saying that the administration had made commitments that convinced him that "the benefits of the designation will far outweigh any detriment"; that the monument would not hurt Maine's [[pulp and paper industry]], and that the monument would help diversify the local economy.[[Richard Pérez-Peña]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/25/us/obama-maine-katahdin-woods-and-waters.html Obama Designates National Monument in Maine, to Dismay of Some], ''New York Times'' (August 24, 2016). King opposes efforts in Maine to ban the baiting and trapping of bears, including an effort to [[Maine Question 1, 2014|put the question to voters in 2014]], calling such practices necessary to prevent interaction between bears and people, and stating the practices are based on science and the views of experts.{{cite web|url=http://georgesoutdoornews.bangordailynews.com/2014/04/05/maine-woods/senator-angus-king-defends-maines-bear-management/ |title=Senator Angus King defends Maine’s bear management |publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=April 6, 2014 |accessdate=April 6, 2014}} ===Immigration=== King strongly criticized President [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Executive Order 13769]], which barred the admission of refugees to the U.S. and barred travel by nationals of several Muslim-majority countries to the country. King stated: "This is probably the worst foreign policy decision since the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]]. What it's done is played right into ISIS's hands. They want us to turn this into a war of the west against Islam. They have explicitly said they want to drive a wedge ... There are 1.6 billion Muslims in the world and we don't want a war with all of them. We don't need a war with all of them. We're not opposed to all of them."Rebecca Savransky, [http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/317036-angus-king-trump-travel-bad-worst-foreign-policy-decision-since-iraq Angus King: Trump travel ban 'worst foreign policy decision' since Iraq war], ''The Hill''(January 31, 2017). King noted that U.S. forces fought alongside Muslim Iraqi troops, and that much valuable [[counterterrorism]] intelligence was shared with the U.S. by Muslim nations. ===Gun laws=== King supports expanding background checks to most firearms transactions, with exceptions for transfers between family members, calling such a position "the single most effective step" that can be taken to keep guns out of the wrong hands. He supports limiting the size of magazines to 10 rounds, and to make purchasing a gun for someone not legally allowed to have one a federal crime. He does not support a ban on assault weapons, believing it will not work and that such a ban is not based on the functionality of the weapons, which are not relevantly different from the many hunting rifles owned by Maine residents. He noted that the vast majority of gun crimes are committed with [[handgun]]s, not rifles.{{cite news|last=King|first=Angus|title=Angus King presents his position on gun control|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/04/11/opinion/angus-king-presents-his-position-on-gun-control/|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=April 11, 2013|accessdate=April 18, 2013}} King voted for the Manchin–Toomey amendment to expand background checks for gun purchases.{{cite news | author=Kevin Miller | title=Collins, King support gun law | url=http://www.kjonline.com/politics/collins-says-she-supports-gun-law_2013-04-14.html | newspaper=Kennebec Journal | date=April 14, 2013 | accessdate=October 28, 2013}} ===Health issues=== King supports the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (ACA or Obamacare), but has expressed support for modest adjustments to the legislation if they can be done on a bipartisan basis.Steve Collins, [http://bangordailynews.com/2017/01/12/news/nation/angus-king-susan-collins-split-on-repeal-of-obamacare/ Angus King, Susan Collins split on repeal of Obamacare], ''Sun Journal'' (January 12, 2017).Burgess Everett & Jennifer Haberkorn, [http://www.politico.com/story/2016/12/democrats-open-to-replacing-obamacare-232589 Democrats open to replacing Obamacare: A surprising number of lawmakers in the minority say they'd play ball if the changes aren't too far-reaching], ''Politico'' (December 15, 2016). In 2013, King voted to restore funding for the ACA as part of an amendment to legislation that [[Continuing resolution|funded government operations]] for 45 days.{{cite web| url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=113&session=1&vote=00208 | title=U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records Home > Votes > S.Amdt.1974 | publisher=Senate.gov | date= |accessdate=September 27, 2013}} He has said that those opposed to the ACA who are attempting to discourage people from purchasing health insurance are "guilty of murder" and that doing so was "one of the grossest violations of our humanity that I could think of."{{cite web| url=http://www.salon.com/2013/09/30/senator_conservatives_encouraging_people_to_skip_obamacare_are_murderers/ | title=Right-wing extremists 'are guilty of murder', Sen. Angus King tells Salon | publisher=Salon.com | date= |accessdate=September 30, 2013}} In making this comment, King noted a time in his life when he believed he would have died had he not just acquired health insurance. In January 2017, King voted against the Republican Senate budget plan to accelerate repeal of the ACA and block repeal legislation from being filibustered; the measure passed on a party line 51-48 vote. He spoke out against the [[American Health Care Act|House Republican repeal legislation]], noting that the [[Congressional Budget Office]] estimated that 14 million Americans would lose health insurance if the legislation were enacted.David Lawder, [http://bangordailynews.com/2017/03/13/politics/gop-health-care-revision-would-reduce-insured-numbers-by-24-million/ Budget office says GOP health care plan would leave millions uninsured], Reuters (March 13, 2017). King stated that the House Republican bill, "If you were designing a bill to hammer my state, it would be this bill," saying that it would most adversely affect Maine residents between the ages of 50–65.Alexander Bolton, [http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/323169-maine-senator-house-gop-healthcare-plan-hammers-my-state "Maine senator: House GOP healthcare plan hammers my state",] ''The Hill'' (March 9, 2017). King is a supporter of the [[Children's Health Insurance Program]] (CHIP) program.Robert Pear, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/19/us/politics/chip-childrens-health-insurance-program-congress.html "With Children's Health Program Running Dry, Parents Beg Congress: 'Do the Right Thing{{'"}},] ''New York Times'' (December 19, 2017). King favors [[abortion rights]].Michael Shepherd, [http://www.pressherald.com/2012/08/22/candidates-stand-firm-as-abortion-debates-swirl_2012-08-23/ Maine candidates stand firm on abortion beliefs], ''Kennebec Journal'' (August 22, 2012). King criticized Trump's 2017 budget proposal for its cuts to medical research.[http://www.pressherald.com/2017/03/16/maines-congressional-delegation-responds-to-trump-budget/ Maine's congressional delegation responds to Trump budget], ''Portland Press Herald'' (March 16, 2017). In 2018, King voted with all Republicans except [[Rand Paul]] and six other Democrats to confirm [[Alex Azar]], Trump's nominee for Health Secretary.{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/370511-senate-advances-trumps-health-secretary-nominee|title=Senate confirms Trump health secretary|last=Cohn|first=Alicia|date=2018-01-24|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/24/us/politics/alex-azar-health-and-human-services-secretary-confirmed-senate.html|title=Senate Confirms Trump Nominee Alex Azar as Health Secretary|access-date=2018-10-30|language=en}} King has voted against Republican attempts to completely defund [[Planned Parenthood]], calling the proposals an "unfounded yet relentless assault" and "another example of misguided outrage that would only hurt those who need help the most."Michael Sherperd, [http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2015/12/04/collins-king-vote-against-senate-bid-to-defund-planned-parenthood/ Collins, King vote against Senate bid to defund Planned Parenthood], ''Bangor Daily News'' (December 4, 2015). No federal funds go to Planned Parenthood for abortions (federal dollars pay for other health care services provided by the group, such as [[contraception]] and screenings for cancer and [[sexually transmitted diseases]]), but Republicans have sought to completely defund the organization because it provides abortions with other funds.Scott Thistle, [http://bangordailynews.com/2015/08/04/politics/collins-and-king-take-issue-with-bill-to-defund-planned-parenthood/ Collins and King take issue with bill to defund Planned Parenthood], ''Sun Journal'' (August 4, 2015). King stated that supporters of the bill were in effect voting to deprive low-income Americans of healthcare over an issue "that has nothing to do with the 97 percent of the services that Planned Parenthood provides," saying: "To me, this bill is like attacking Brazil after [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]]." ===Same-sex marriage=== King supports [[Same-sex marriage in Maine|same-sex marriage]].{{cite news|last1=Dolan|first1=Scott|title=Maine reacts to Supreme Court ruling affirming same-sex marriage in all states|url=https://www.pressherald.com/2015/06/26/maine-reacts-to-supreme-court-ruling-affirming-same-sex-marriage-in-all-states/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Portland Press Herald|date=June 26, 2015}} He signed an [[Amicus curiae|amicus brief]] to the [[United States Supreme Court|U.S. Supreme Court]] in ''[[United States v. Windsor]]'' encouraging it to strike down the [[Defense of Marriage Act]].{{cite news|last=Long|first=Robert|title=King, Pingree and Michaud want courts to strike federal ban on same-sex marriage|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/03/01/politics/maines-king-pingree-and-michaud-sign-brief-asking-high-court-to-strike-federal-ban-on-same-sex-marriage/|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|date=March 1, 2013|accessdate=April 7, 2013}} == Electoral history == {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="5" |Maine gubernatorial election, 1994 |- |'''Party''' |'''Candidate''' |'''Votes''' |'''%''' |'''+%''' |- |Independent |'''Angus King''' |180,829 |35% | |- |Democratic |Joseph Brennan |172,951 |34% | |- |Republican |Susan Collins |117,990 |23% | |- |Green |Jonathan Carter |32,695 |6% | |- |Write-in |Ed Finks |6,576 |1% | |} {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="5" |Maine gubernatorial election, 1998 |- |'''Party''' |'''Candidate''' |'''Votes''' |'''%''' |'''+%''' |- |Independent |'''Angus King (inc.)''' |246,772 |59% | |- |Republican |James Longley Jr. |79,716 |19% | |- |Democratic |Thomas Connolly |50,506 |12% | |- |Green |Pat LaMarche |28,722 |7% | |- |Constitution |William Clarke Jr. |15,293 |4% | |} {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="5" |U.S. Senate election in Maine, 2012 |- |'''Party''' |'''Candidate''' |'''Votes''' |'''%''' |'''+%''' |- |Independent |'''Angus King''' |370,580 |51% | |- |Republican |Charles Summers Jr. |215,399 |30% | |- |Democratic |Cynthia Ann Dill |92,900 |13% | |- |Independent |Stephen Woods |10,289 |1% | |- |Independent |Danny Francis Dalton |5,807 |1% | |- |Independent |Andrew Ian Dodge |5,624 |1% | |} ==Personal life== King's first wife was Edie Birney.{{cite web|url=https://www.pressherald.com/2012/09/22/the-making-of-a-man-without-a-party_2012-09-23/|title=The making of a man without a party|date=September 22, 2012|publisher=}} She is the mother of King's oldest son, Angus Stanley King III.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/26/style/weddings-ms-alexandre-and-mr-king.html|title=WEDDINGS; Ms. Alexandre And Mr. King|publisher=}} King and Birney divorced in 1982. In 1984, King married Mary Herman, his current wife. King has five children and six grandchildren.{{cite web|url=https://www.king.senate.gov/about/biography |title=About Angus |publisher=King.senate.gov |accessdate=June 8, 2017}} King is an [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopalian]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/news/the-making-of-a-man-without-a-party_2012-09-23.html?pagenum=full|title=The making of a man without a party The former governor's view of the world was shaped long before be [sic] ran for public office, and will likely continue to inform his choices.|author=Colin Woodard|date=September 23, 2012|publisher=''[[Portland Press Herald]]''}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/02/15/politics/angus-king-senate|title=Independent's Day: King hopes to bridge divided D.C.|author=Alan Silverleib|date=February 15, 2013|publisher=cnn.com}} He rides a [[Harley-Davidson]] motorcycle.{{cite news|last1=Bayly|first1=Julia|title=Senate candidate Angus King looking for adventure on his Harley|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/07/23/politics/elections/senate-candidate-angus-king-looking-for-adventure-on-his-harley/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Bangor Daily News|date=July 23, 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Angus King}} *[https://king.senate.gov/ Senator Angus King] official U.S. Senate website * [https://angusformaine.com Campaign website] *{{Dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Maine/Government/Federal/US_Senate/Angus_King_%5BI%5D}} * {{CongLinks | congbio=K000383 | votesmart=22381 | fec=S2ME00109 | congress=angus-king/2185 }} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[John R. {{advert|date=October 2009}} {{essay-like|date=October 2009}} The '''Architectural Woodwork Institute''' (AWI), founded in 1953, is a [[Industry trade group|professional trade association]]. Member companies are the fabricators of fine finished [[woodwork]], [[Millwork (building material)|millwork]], and [[furniture]]. AWI has published a Standard of Care for woodworking since 1961, called the [[Quality Standards Illustrated]].
The association is built on the idea of sharing knowledge in many forms – formal programs, seminars and workshops, networking, committee involvement and publications.
AWI and its members is devoted to fostering professionalism throughout the industry. Each member firm today garners prestige through the AWI logo, Quality Standards, Quality Certification Program, Design Solutions and other important technical publications.
AWI Chapters are integral to networking opportunities, sharing of resources, and overall association operations. Chapters are the bedrock upon which the association operates. The chapter structure provides influence, information and a united front on local levels, bringing a common voice to the national organization on important industry issues. Chapters also provide the opportunity to conduct grassroots educational programs for woodworkers and the design community. They bring together woodworkers in a local area, giving them the opportunity to share ideas and information specific to their region.
The AWI is not related to the Woodworkers Institute website in any way.
==History== Since its beginning as the ''Millwork Cost Bureau'', the Architectural Woodwork Institute has evolved into a respected organization. A small group gathered in [[Chicago]] on December 12, 1952 to determine if new life could be infused into the existing organization, or whether a new, more dynamic association should be formed to represent the expanding core of special millwork operators. Their first meeting set in motion a series of gatherings that would lead them down a new path. One month later, in January 1953, Charles Rinehimer, president of Rinehimer Bros. Mfg. Company, [[Elgin, Illinois]], met with Ormie Lance, manager of the National Woodwork Manufacturers Association representing the 31 stock millwork plants in the [[United States]]. The conversation drifted in the direction of conducting a national meeting of custom millworkers, with the suggestion of running the idea past a trade association management firm. On October 15, 1953, Chairman Rinehimer welcomed 176 representatives of 109 architectural woodwork companies from the United States and Canada, 10 suppliers, representatives from 11 interested trade associations and 9 guest speakers to the opening session of a two-day convention at the Congress Hotel in Chicago. Concluding the discussions and the recommendation of the Development Committee, a motion was unanimously affirmed, creating the Architectural Woodwork Institute. After the convention adjourned, the newly elected directors met to select the first slate of officers: Rinehimer as president, Claude Twiellenmeier as first vice president, Charles Fischer as second vice president, William Otis as third vice president, and Elmer Root as treasurer. After the officers were selected, Robert Hoe, Jr., the director from Poughkeepsie, handed the new treasurer his company check for the first year’s dues, and the Architectural Woodwork Institute was on its way. Shortly thereafter, AWI was incorporated as a non-profit organization under the laws of the state of [[Illinois]]. Articles of Incorporation were recorded on December 17, 1954.
Chairman Rinehimer helped to form regional chapters throughout the country. Membership in AWI increased as a result and a dual membership package for AWI and MCB was developed. [[cost book|Cost Book]] A was revised with plans set in motion to form an upgraded estimators correspondence course. AWI is a hands-on organization, governed by a member board, slate of officers and a set of bylaws. An industry association run by members, AWI programs and policies are developed and monitored by committees, and administered by an executive director and a national headquarters staff.
Elected officers are the primary governing body of the organization. The president accepts the gavel for a one-year term following several years of service in board and vice president slots.
In the late 1990s a [[management consulting]] group was enlisted to study the Institute’s governance structure. A member task force was appointed to work with the consulting team and together they studied and evaluated board design, nomination processes, committee structure and roles and responsibilities. At first the task force’s recommendations were rejected by the board, requiring further study and discussion, and then approved in the spring of 2001, reducing the size of the board to eleven members, eliminating the Executive Committee, and establishing a Development Council.
==References== * ''8th Edition Quality Standards Illustrated (QSI)'' - Introduction - Potomac Falls, Virginia - 2003 [http://www.awinet.org]
==External links== * Official Website http://awinet.org/

{{refimprove|date=June 2013}} '''B205''' is the name of the [[Magnox]] [[nuclear reprocessing]] plant at [[Sellafield]] in northern England. This plant uses [[PUREX]] chemistry (based on [[tributyl phosphate]] (TBP)) to extract [[plutonium]] and [[uranium]] from [[used nuclear fuel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ieer.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/1997/01/no-2.pdf|title=The International Civilian Reprocessing Business|work=Energy and Security|publisher=[[Institute for Energy and Environmental Research]]|first=Frans|last=Berkhout|year=1997|accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> The plant was originally constructed and operated by the [[United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority]] (UKAEA), but in 1971 control was transferred to [[British Nuclear Fuels Limited]] (BNFL).
B205 was commissioned in 1964 as a replacement for the UK's first nuclear reprocessing plant, B204, which was converted into a pre-handling plant for B205 and recommissioned in 1969. In 1973, after both plants had been shut down for one year for repairs, a violent reaction in the B204 plant occurred which contaminated the entire plant and 34 workers with [[ruthenium]]-106. Following this event the B204 plant was permanently decommissioned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellona.no/en/energy/nuclear/sellafield/wp_5-2001/21738.html |title=Reprocessing plant B204 |accessdate=January 7, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051124164632/http://www.bellona.no/en/energy/nuclear/sellafield/wp_5-2001/21738.html |archivedate=November 24, 2005 }}</ref> A similar [[Ruthenium tetroxide|ruthenium oxidation]] and sublimation reaction occurred in [[Airborne radioactivity increase in Europe in autumn 2017|2017 in the Mayak reprocessing facility]] in southern Russia.<ref>[http://www.irsn.fr/EN/newsroom/News/Pages/20171109_Detection-of-Ruthenium-106-in-France-and-in-Europe-Results-of-IRSN-investigations.aspx Detection of Ruthenium 106 in France and in Europe: Results of IRSN’s investigations]</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/11/11/radioactive-cloud-that-covered-europe-might-be-from-russia-dont-worry-about-it-though/?noredirect=on Radioactive cloud that covered Europe might be from Russia]</ref><ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com/r-russia-starts-cleaning-up-cold-war-era-nuclear-waste-2017-6?IR=T Russia starts cleaning up Cold War-era nuclear waste 2017. "from Andreyeva Bay, the spent fuel will be shipped on board a specially-equipped vessel to Russia's Arctic port of Murmansk, then on to its final destination, the Mayak nuclear reprocessing plant in Chelyabinsk, near the Ural Mountains."]</ref>
Over its lifetime, the B205 plant has handled over 35,000 tons of expended Magnox fuel, and returned over 15,000 tons of uranium to the fuel cycle. Now that the Magnox reactors have been retired from use, the final fuels are being processed, and the B205 plant is slated for decommissioning around 2020 after all fuel has been reprocessed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellona.no/en/energy/nuclear/sellafield/wp_5-2001/21739.html |title=Magnox Reprocessing Plant (B205) |accessdate=March 29, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051128051748/http://www.bellona.no/en/energy/nuclear/sellafield/wp_5-2001/21739.html |archivedate=November 28, 2005 }}</ref>
==Process== The process uses mixer settlers as the basis of the plant operation. The Magnox fuel is dissolved in nitric acid within the Dissolver Cell. The aqueous stream is conditioned to the correct temperature and acidity and then passes to the first mixer settler system where fission products are separated from the uranium (U) and plutonium (Pu) by extraction of the U/Pu into the solvent phase comprising tri-butyl-phosphate in odourless kerosene. This has the effect of reducing the radiation levels in subsequent stages of the process and the resulting degradation of the solvents.
The solvent stream of U, Pu and remaining fission products then passes to the critical mixer settler stages where the U and Pu are transferred into the aqueous phase and fission products remains in the aqueous phase. Separation of the U and Pu is achieved by adding a reductant, which causes the Pu, but not the U, to transfer into the solvent phase. Once separated, further removal of fission products is undertaken by more mixer settler units.
The U and Pu streams are then passed to evaporators to concentrate the U and PU before further processing in other plants.
==See also== * [[Reprocessed uranium]] * [[Mixer-settler]]

[[H-M symbol]]: (mm2) | symmetry = ''Pn''21a | unit cell = a = 13.8378 Å,
b = 12.3781 Å,
c = 14.9238 Å; Z = 4 | color = | colour = Amber-yellow, golden to lemon-yellow, yellow-orange, brownish yellow | habit = Tabular prismatic striated crystals exhibiting pseudohexagonal outline; coatings and fine-grained aggregates | twinning = | cleavage = Perfect on {001}; imperfect on {101}, {010} and {110} | fracture = | tenacity = Brittle | mohs = 2.5 | lustre = Adamantine to greasy | streak = Yellow | diaphaneity = Transparent | gravity = 5.09 - 5.2 | density = | polish = | opticalprop = Biaxial (-) | refractive = nα = 1.725 - 1.735 nβ = 1.815 - 1.825 nγ = 1.825 - 1.830 | birefringence = δ = 0.100 | pleochroism = X = colourless to pale yellow, Y = Z = yellow to deep yellow | 2V = Measured: 32° | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = Commonly contains lead | alteration = | other = [[Radioactive]] | references = [http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/doclib/hom/becquerelite.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy][http://www.mindat.org/min-597.html Mindat.org][http://www.webmineral.com/data/Becquerelite.shtml Webmineral data] }} '''Becquerelite''' is a [[uranium]] mineral with the chemical formula: Ca(UO2)6O4(OH)6·8(H2O). It is a secondary mineral which contains [[calcium]] and is a bright yellow colour. It has a [[Mohs hardness]] of about 2. It was named after the French physicist [[Antoine Henri Becquerel]] (1852–1908), who discovered radioactivity in 1896. Becquerelite contains about 70% uranium by weight. It is mainly mined in Kasolo of the former [[Zaire]], in the present day [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{-}} [[Category:Uranium minerals]] [[Category:Oxide minerals]] [[Category:Orthorhombic minerals]] [[Category:Uranium mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] {{Oxide-mineral-stub}}

The '''Canadian Renewable Fuels Association''' (CRFA) is a non-profit organization in Canada, created in 1984. In 2016, CRFA re-launched under the name '''Renewable Industries Canada''' (RICanada). The change reinforced the 32 year-old non-profit association's mission to promote the use of value-added products made from renewable resources.<ref>[http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/renewable-industries-canada-becomes-new-face-canadas-biofuels-bio-based-sectors-2128936.htm Renewable Industries Canada Becomes New Face of Canada's Bio Based Sectors]</ref> RICanada represents the interests of over 30 member companies, and is Canada's leading voice in promoting the role of renewable fuels and value added products in reducing GHG emissions.
Its stated purpose is to "To promote the use of value-added products made from renewable resources through consumer awareness and government liaison activities."<ref>[http://ricanada.org/about/background/] RICanada About</ref>
==Leadership== RICanada is currently led by an Executive Director and reports to a Board of Directors <ref>[http://ricanada.org/about/team/ RICanada Team]</ref> after being previously led by a number of dedicated Presidents. Past Presidents include Andrea Kent (2014-2017),<ref>[http://ricanada.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/30-10-2014-andrea-kent-appointed-crfa-president.pdf] Andrea Kent Appointed CRFA President</ref> W. Scott Thurlow (2012-2014), and Gordon Quaiattini (2007-2014).<ref>[http://ricanada.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/070711-gordon-quaiattini-resignation.pdf] Gordon Quaiattini Announces Departure From CRFA</ref> Before 2007, RICanada was led by [[Kory Teneycke]], a former activist with the [[Reform Party of Canada]], and a veteran of the [[Conservative Party of Canada]]'s war room for the [[Canadian federal election, 2006|2006 federal election]]. At the time, one of the CRFA's registered lobbyists is Ken Boessenkool, a confidant of Conservative [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]].<ref>[http://www.canada.com/topics/news/national/story.html?id=bd9e5d7d-ffc1-4144-b20b-71ecf107ef0f&k=80908 Bruce Cheadle, "Harper slammed as 'hypocrite' over lawyer lobbyist"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025083922/http://www.canada.com/topics/news/national/story.html?id=bd9e5d7d-ffc1-4144-b20b-71ecf107ef0f&k=80908# |date=2012-10-25 }}, ''Canadian Press'', 8 March 2007, accessed 24 March 2007.</ref>
==Advocacy==
In 2017, RICanada launched a public awareness campaign on the environmental and economic benefits of biofuels mandates. Dubbed 'Facts Don't Lie', the campaign was designed to educate the public on the role of biofuels in reducing carbon emissions from transportation. The underlying message of the campaign was a call to the federal government to increase mandates for renewable content in fuels. [https://www.canadianbiomassmagazine.ca/news/ricanada-launches-ad-campaign-to-promote-biofuels-6643 "RICanada Launches Ad Campaign to Promote Biofuels"] Facts included:
• Ethanol can reduce GHGs by 62 per cent compared to gasoline.
• Biodiesel can reduce GHGs by over 100 per cent compared to diesel.
• Canada's biofuels mandates reduce annual GHG emissions to the same extent as taking one million cars off the road.
• Each year, Canada's biofuels mandate removes as much C02 from the atmosphere as 21 million trees.
• Increasing the federal biofuels mandate could add 31,000 jobs and $5.6 billion to Canada's economy.
• Canada was once a world leader in implementing renewable fuel requirements. Today, over 40 countries require higher levels of biofuel blends in transportation fuels than Canada.<ref>[http://ricanada.org/facts-dont-lie/ RICanada Facts Don't Lie]</ref>
In 2007, the CRFA ran television advertisements promoting a Conservative Party pledge on renewable fuels, and the 5% renewable fuel standard in all transportation fuels in Canada. The advertisements featured images of Stephen Harper, as well as an interview with Conservative candidate [[Peter Kent]]. The policy itself has broad political support: the Liberal Party of Canada also supports a 5% renewable fuels standard, and former Saskatchewan NDP Premier Lorne Calvert promoted a 10% biofuels mandate.
